references: Johnson, D.H. 1943. Systematic review of the chipmunks (genus Eutamias) of California. University of California Publications in Zoology, 48:63-148.
Negus, N.C., and J.S. Findley. 1959. Mammals of Jackson Hole, Wyoming. Journal of Mammalogy 40:371–381.
Bergstrom, B. J. 1988. Home ranges of three species of chipmunks Tamias as assessed by radiotelemetry and grid trapping. Journal of Mammalogy, 69(1):190-193.
Hall, Raymond E. 1946. Mammals of Nevada University of California Press, Berkely and Los Angeles, California.
Hock, R. J. 1963. Mammals of the White Mountain range, California. Univ. Calif. White Mt. Res. Sta. 5pp.
Fitzgerald, J.P., C. A. Meaney, and D. M. Armstrong. 1994. Mammals of Colorado. Denver Museum of Natural History and University Press of Colorado: Niwot, Colorado. 467 pp.
California Department of Fish and Game. 2003. California Wildlife Habitat Relationships System. http://www.dfg.ca.gov/whdab/html/cawildlife.html.
Burt, W.H. and R.P. Grossenheider. 1976. A Field Guide to Mammals, Third edition. Houghton Mifflin Company. Boston, MA. 289 pp.
Hoffmeister, D.F. 1986. Mammals of Arizona. University of Arizona Press. The University of Arizona Press and the Arizona Game and Fish Department, Tucson, Arizona. 602 pages.
Long, C. A., and D. Cronkite. 1970. Taxonomy and ecology of sibling chipmunks in central Colorado.  Southwestern Naturalist 14:283–291.
Hayward, C. L. 1945. Biotic communities of the southern Wasatch and Uinta mountains, Utah. Great Basin Naturalist 6:1–124.
Armstrong, D.M. 1972. Distribution of mammals in Colorado. University of Kansas, Mus. of Nat. Hist., Monograph No. 3, Lawrence.
Zeiner, D. C., et al., editors. 1990. California's wildlife. Vol. II. Mammals. California Dept. Fish & Game, Sacramento. xi + 407 pp.
Cary, A.B., R.G. McLean, and G.O. Maupin. 1980. The structure of a Colorado tick fever ecosystem. Ecological Monographs 50:131–151.
Braun, J.K., A.A. Johnson, and M.A. Mares 2011. Tamias umbrinus. The American Society of Mammalogists, Mammalian Species 43(889):216-227.
habitat_description:
Southwest:
“Coniferous forests (yellow pine zone) up to timberline; rocky slopes” (Burt & Grossenheider 1976).  “.. Preferred habitat is among the conifers - yellow pines, white pines, and other conifers of high zonal position - which grow at an elevation higher than the pinyons and junipers ….. A few, but not many, in thick stands of aspen, and at lower elevation, they were common about ledges of rock and were found in mountain mahogany and in rock slides… ventured into pinyon-juniper, but only a short way” (Hall 1946).  “… optimal habitat is open, subalpine conifer forest of whitebark, foxtail, limber, and bristlecone pines.  “In northwestern Colorado it occupies pinyon-juniper woodlands and montane shrublands, where it was considered uncommon… More commonly, it occurs in higher elevation forest-edge situations in montane and subalpine forests (especially lodgepole pine on rubbly moraines), and it sometimes ranges into the alpine..” (Fitzgerald et al. 1994).  “in Arizona … in habitats of ponderosa pine, white fir, subalpine fir, blue spruces, and quaking aspen.  Near the rim of the Grand Canyon they sometimes live among pinyons, junipers, and scrub oak…” (Hoffmeister 1986).  Elevation:  6000-11,000 feet (1829-3353 m) elevation (Burt & Grossenheider 1976); in White Mountains of eastern California, 2650-3450 m (8200-11,000 feet) (CDFG 2003); in Colorado, 1980-3660 m (Fitzgerald et al. 1994). In California, this species inhabits high elevation, open subalpine conifer forests in the Inyo and White Mountains and the southern Sierra Nevada especially on exposed slopes or ridges at or near timberline. Preferred conifer species include whitebark, foxtail, limber, and bristlecone pines. Elevation ranges from 2360 m to 3450m (Hock 1963, Johnson 1943, [Harris 1995] based on Zeiner et al. 1990). In Colorado, T. umbrinus occupies montane forest, montane subalpine meadows, subalpine forest, ponderosa pine-Douglas fir forest, as well as pinyon-juniper woodlands and montane shrublands (Armstron 1972, Bergstrom 1988, Fitzgerald et al. 1994, Braun et al. 2011). This species may also occupy riparian areas of cottonwood-willow river bottoms (Long and Cronkite 1970), and frequents rocky areas and talus slopes (Cary et al. 1980, Fitzgerald et al. 1994, Braun et al. 2011).

Northwest:
In Wyoming, T. umbrinus occupies spruce-fir forest edges of clearings and meadows, as well as cliffs above timberline (Negus and Findley 1959). In Utah, this species can be found in ponderosa pine to the subalpine zone and in conifer climax and subclimax upper montane spruce-fir forests, but is absent or rare in lower montane forest habitats (Hayward 1945, Braun et al. 2011).
